sub_topic: Probability of a certain type of educational outcome occurring in a school
message_1: A school has 120 students taking a math course. There are 60 males and 60 females. If the probability of a male student passing the course is 0.8, and the probability of a female student passing the course is 0.6, what is the probability that exactly 45 male students and 30 female students will pass the course?
message_2:
To solve this problem, we will use the binomial probability formula:

P(x) = C(n, x) * p^x * (1-p)^(n-x)

where P(x) is the probability of exactly x successes in n trials, C(n, x) is the number of combinations of n items taken x at a time, p is the probability of success, and (1-p) is the probability of failure.

First, we will find the probability of exactly 45 male students passing the course:

n = 60 (number of male students)
x = 45 (number of male students passing)
p = 0.8 (probability of a male student passing)

C(60, 45) = 60! / (45! * (60-45)!)
P(45 males pass) = C(60, 45) * 0.8^45 * 0.2^15

Next, we will find the probability of exactly 30 female students passing the course:

n = 60 (number of female students)
x = 30 (number of female students passing)
p = 0.6 (probability of a female student passing)

C(60, 30) = 60! / (30! * (60-30)!)
P(30 females pass) = C(60, 30) * 0.6^30 * 0.4^30

Finally, we will multiply the probabilities of these two independent events to find the probability of both events occurring:

P(45 males pass and 30 females pass) = P(45 males pass) * P(30 females pass)

Calculating the values:

C(60, 45) = 5,461,512,070
P(45 males pass) = 5,461,512,070 * 0.8^45 * 0.2^15 ≈ 0.0013

C(60, 30) = 1,182,052,560
P(30 females pass) = 1,182,052,560 * 0.6^30 * 0.4^30 ≈ 0.0215

P(45 males pass and 30 females pass) = 0.0013 * 0.0215 ≈ 0.00002795

So, the probability that exactly 45 male students and 30 female students will pass the course is approximately 0.002795 or 0.2795%.
